DIV1.HEAD: To the CHRISTIAN Reader, the sauing knowledge of that truth which is accor∣dingTitus 1. 1 to godlinesse.
DIV1.P:
CHRISTIAN Reader: this short Catechism, thus gathered & set downe for the help of the ignorant, cannot be called new, but renewed for their sakes. For, I may say in this case as Salomon in his Ecclesiastes, saydEccles. 1. 9 a like case: What is that that hath been? that that shal be. And what is that that hath been done? that that shall be done: and there is o new thing vnder the Sunne.
The portion of meate which is heere offered to the taste of the simple, is no other then that which he hath alrea∣dy tasted of, if hec haue tasted any thing of the things of God: and it is but the substance of other Catchisms set before him in another kinde of seruice, that is, with some difference of Cookery and dressing: which (con∣sidering our too great distaste with one kinde of meate, though neuer so wholsome, if wee be continually fedde with it without diuersitie) may not be without some good vse, at least for some short time. For, the affections of men stand no lesse diuersly affe∣cted towards the variety of Gods gifts, in deliuering one and the same matter, then doth the stomake to∣ward the dressing of one and the same kind of meate in a diuers man∣ner, by some-alteration of forme and manner of doing it. And yet it is part of my meaning to hold vp the
market of nolty by sch eye∣seruice, as tedeth rather tickle the care, then to satisfie the sder iudgement: or to say any thing for those who make bookes like to the ap∣parell which they weare, fashi∣os that they are weary of▪ when a wer comes. Only, hauing taught these Principles (most of them) a few pritely; and finding it more easie to print them▪ then to write them, or the surer keeping of them in their memories, who had leared them, and the good of abroad that desired them; I was not vnwil∣ling thus to giue them content by the benefit of the resse and of pting. Neither haue I done this for any wnt: for there is store of Catechisms abroad, to which this worme of mine is no way comparable: and God hath mercifll with our age for the meanes of knowledge; but we famish spiritlly at the ful measure of these
, either by vsing them all, or shld.

This of I could haue made larger, but that I csidered my Cruse of st, the Vessels that I had to fill, which could. King. 4. 4. 6 well recei more, and so left pou∣ring, as I pered their filling. Ac∣cept therefore (Reader) what is here offered to thy gentlenesse, and take it in good part, as it is meant vnto thee. And so, I thee, and thy groth in to the grace assistce of Almighty God: and rest,

DIV3.P: In the first of the fiue, which is: Commande∣ment. honour thy Father, and thy Mother, &c.

P.HI: What doe you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The occassion, and matter of the Commandement.

P.HI: What was the occasion?

DIV3.P: Our proud nature that cannot a∣bidePsalme 12. 4. Luk 19. 14. 27. Ephesians 2 2. to be vnder gouernment.

P.HI: What say you of the matter?

DIV3.P: It may be considered in the parti∣cular duties, and persons.

P.HI: Vnder what word are the duties specified?

DIV3.P: Under the word honour: by which is meant all subiection of bodie and minde in the Lord.

P.HI: What is the subiection of the body?

DIV3.P: Gen 48. 12. 1. Kings 1. 23. & 2. 19 Obeisance or outward seruice▪

P.HI: Wherein standeth that?

DIV3.P: Col. 3. 20 21. Luk 2. 51. Gen. 22 6 7 9 Ephe 5. 24. 1. Tim 5 4. Gen 47 12. Ruth. 2. 18. In obedience, and thankfulnesse.

P.HI: How must we obey?
VVherein standeth our thankful∣nesse?

DIV3.P: In procuring their good, and in praying for them.

P.HI: Somuch for the subiection of the body; what is that of the minde?

DIV3.P: The inward estimation, loue, and reuerence that we beare them.

P.HI: Somuch for the duties: what are the persons to whom wee owe these duties.

DIV3.P: All superiors comprehended vn∣derRom. 13. 1 the names of Father & Mother.

P.HI: Of what sort are these?

DIV3.P: They are publike, or priuate.

P.HI: VVhat are the publike?

DIV3.P: Such as are in the common∣wealth,1. Pet. 2. 13, 14 Heb. 13. 17 1. The. 5. 12, 13 as the King and his Magi∣strates: or in the Church, as Pastors and other Ministers.

P.HI: VVhat are the priuate?

DIV3.P: Such as are in the family, as Pa∣rents,Eph. 6. 1. Colos. 3. 22 Eph. 6▪ , 6, 7 Tit. 2. 9. Leu. 19. 32. Esa. 3. 5 Rom. 13. 2 Tit. 3. 1. Masters, and Dames: or out of it, as the ancients of our kindred, and olde men: to all these wee must submit in y• Lord with all reuerence, loue and humility; likewise to euery ordinance that God hath set vp for gouernment.

P.HI: So much for the precept belonging to Superiours: What Commande∣ments belong to others?

DIV3.P: The foure next.

P.HI: How are they diuided?

DIV3.P: Into duties belonging to their persons, and into duties, in things that belong to their persons.

P.HI: What are the duties belonging to their persons?

DIV3.P: Innocency in the next, and purity in the seuenth Commandement.

P.HI: What are the words of the next Commandement?

DIV3.P: Thou shalt not kill.Sixt Comman∣dement.

P.HI: VVhat doe you consider therein?

DIV3.P: The occasion, and matter there∣of.

P.HI: VVhat was the occasion?

DIV3.P: Our fierce and murtherous na∣ture.Ioh. 8. 44. Ezek 16. 3. Mat. 3. 7.

P.HI: VVhat say you of the matter?

DIV3.P: It forbiddeth to shedde blood, andGen. 9. 6. Pro. 24. 11. . Kings 18. 4. 1. Sam. 19 1. 2. Esth. 4. 13. 14. Psal. 82. 4. Iob 29. 17. commandeth to preserue life. Or, it forbiddeth vs to bee Authors of wrong; and chargeth vs neither to suffer it, nor to be abettors to it.

P.HI: How may blood be shed, or wrong done?
How inwardly?

DIV3.P: By rash anger, malice, enuie, ha∣tred, desire of reuenge, vnmerciful∣nesse, and other cruell affections, which (within) draw much bloud.

P.HI: How outwardly?

DIV3.P: By our words, or deeds.

P.HI: How by our words?

DIV3.P: By mocks, taunts, reproches; byLeuit. 19. 14. Ier. 20. 8. 10. Gen. 21. 9. Pro. 12. 18. 1. Cor. 6. 10. 1. Sam. 25 17. Mat. 5. 22. Gen. 31. 5. bitter and cursed speaking; and by churlish and froward talke.

P.HI: How by our deeds?

DIV3.P: Mat. 5. 30. Leuit. 24. 19. 20. Deut. 5. 17. Leuit. 24. 17. 1. Sam. 31. 4. 2. Sam. 17. 23. Mat. 27. 5. 1. Ki. 21. 9. 10. 2. Sā. 11. 15. When we hurt or kill another, or our selues, secretly and cunningly by poyson, or openly with some wea∣pon.

P.HI: So much for that which is forbid∣den: what is commanded?

DIV3.P: Iam. 3 13. Eph. 4. 32. Col. 3. . Iob. 29. 15. Rom. 12 15. M. 5. 9. 1. Cor. 13. 7. Gen. 13. 8. 9. Mat. 25. 36. Iā. 1. 27. Col. 3. 12 1. Tim. 5. 23. Ioh. 8. 59. & 2. 24, 25. Matt. 5. 44. Rō▪ 12, 20. To do whatsoeuer may preserue or cherish our Neighbors life, or our owne: exercising the works of mer∣cy, pitty, compassion, and tendernes toward all, yea; our very enemies.

P.HI: So much for innocencie: what say you of purity?

DIV3.P:
The next precept commandeth it, which forbiddeth Adultery, the con∣trary
thereunto.

P.HI: What are the words?
Thou shalt not commit Adultery.Seuenth Com∣mandement. What do you obserue in them?

DIV3.P: The occasion, and further ope∣ning of them.

P.HI: What was the occasion?

DIV3.P: Our vnchaste & adulterous nature.Esa. 57. 3. Psa. 51. 4. 5. Esa. 1. 4 Hos. 2. 4. Mat. 12. 39. 2. Cor. 7. 1. 1. Thes. 4. 3. 4. 1. Cor▪ 6. 15. 19. Deu. 22 25. 2. Sā. 13. 14.

P.HI: What say you of this further ope∣ning of the Commandement?

DIV3.P: Under the name of Adultery, we are forbidden al vncleanenesse in our selues, or toward others: and com∣manded to vse all meanes for the pre∣seruing of our own, and our neigh∣bours Chastitie.

P.HI: What vncleannes is here forbidden?

DIV3.P: All vncleannes inward & outward.

P.HI: What call you inward vnclean∣nesse?

DIV3.P: The Adultery of the heart in fil∣thyMat. 5. 28. Iam. 1. 14, 15. Ier. 4. 14. Esa. 64. 6. Gen. 6. 3. 5. Ier. 3. 25. usts and desires within consent. Or, the corruption of the soule in vn∣cleane thoughts and fansies contra∣ry to the Commandement.

P.HI: What is outward vncleanenesse?

DIV3.P: It is in word, or deede.

P.HI: What is that in word?

DIV3.P: Uncleane talke and readings toEph. 4. 29. & 5, 3. the corrupting of our selues, and our neighbours; which is the fruit of a whorish tongue.

P.HI: VVhat is that indeede?

DIV3.P: It is in the adulteries them∣selues, or prouocations thereunto.

P.HI: VVhat say you of the adulteries themselues?

DIV3.P: They are of married persons, orHeb. 13. 4. Leu. 19. 29. Deut. 23 17. 1. Cor. 6. 9. when one of the parties is married or contracted, properly called adulte∣rie: and of persons before mariage, called fornication.

P.HI: VVhat is adultery in Mariage?

DIV3.P: An vncleanesse against it in their entrance, or afterward.

P.HI: How may they be said to bee vn∣cleane in their entrance?

DIV3.P: When they marrie within the de∣grees forbidden, without consent of Parents or other Ouerseers; with such as are of no Religion or a flse, and with persons contractd or r∣ried to some other before.

P.HI: How afterward?

DIV3.P: When they with rang lesh, or abuse their own marige.

P.HI: So much for the adulteries them∣selues: what say you of the prouoca∣tions thereunto?

DIV3.P: They belong to the bodie, or are in the body it selfe.

P.HI: VVhat are they that belong to the bodie?

DIV3.P: Deut. 22. 12. Esa. 3. 18. 19. &c. & 4. 4. Zep. 1. 8. Pro. 7. 10. Deu. 22. 5. Eze. 16. 49. Eph. 5. 18. Ier. 5. 8. Pro. 23. 29. 30, 33. Ezek. 23. 14. 1. Pe. 1. 14. Genesis 34. 1 1. Cor. 15. 33. Deut. 22. 21. 2. Sam. 11. 2. Prouerbs 13. 4. Ezek. 16 49. Immodesty to apparel and other deckings of the body: intemperance in meates and drinkes: wantn pic∣tures and , with lewd and wan∣ton pastimes: vncleane songs and dtties: houses of open whoredome: exceiue sleep and idlenesse, with the like.

P.HI: VVhat are they which bee in the body it selfe?

DIV3.P: Al wanton lookings, whisperings,Pro. 6. 13. 2. Pe. 2. 14. Gen. 39. 12. Pro. 7. 10. 11 12, 13, &c. Mat. 14 6. Iob. 21. 11. Rom. 14. 13. touchings, and other impure beha∣uiour stirring vp lust: specially mixt dcing, of men and women, where all dores are set open for whoredome to come in. For, in these, all parts are abused to eshly dalliance, the eie the hand, the mouth, the mincin foote.

P.HI: So much for that which is forbid∣den: what is commanded as the sum of all?

DIV3.P: To keepe our owne bodies and1. Thes. 4. 4. 7. 1. Cor. 1. 2. 1. Pet. 1. 15. Ephesi. 4. 29. 1. Cor. 9. 27. 1. Tim. 2. 9. Tit 2. 3. Rom. 13. 13. Gal. 5. 16. 1. Cor. ▪. 36. Apo. 2. 14. 20. Gal 5. 13. 1. Ioh. 2. 10. 1. Cor. 7. 2. 9. Heb. 13. 4. Pro. 5. 19. & 31. 11. Rom. 7. 2. soules Chaste and pure, as Temples of the Holy Ghost, all helpes thereto, and all meanes in our pow∣er for the like to our neighbour: and, if be not giuen vs without mariage, in mariage to vse the law∣full remedy of and burning.

P.HI: So much for the duties that con∣cerne or Neighbours person: what are they that are in things belonging to their persons?

DIV3.P: They are in the two next Com∣mandements; which, teach vs the care that we owe to them for the pre∣seruing of their goods and good name.

P.HI: Where are we charged with the preseruation of their goods?

DIV3.P: In the next Eight Commande∣ment,Eight Comman∣dement. which is: Thou shal not steale?

P.HI: What doe you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The occasion of the Commande∣ment, and the matter.

P.HI: What was the occasion?

DIV3.P: Our conetous and nature, not contented with our .

P.HI: What doe you consider in the matter of the Commandement?

DIV3.P: The things forbidden and com∣manded.

P.HI: What is the thing forbidden?

DIV3.P: Theft, which is a violent and open, or secret and craftie taking away, or diminishing of our neighbors goods, and lauish spending of our own.

P.HI: Of what sorts is it?

DIV3.P: Inward, and outward.

P.HI: What is the inward Theft?

DIV3.P: The theft of the heart, or that co∣uetousnesse2. Pet. 2. 14. Ios. 7. 21. 1. Kin. 21 4. Eph. 5. 5. which is Idolatry.

P.HI: What is the outward?

DIV3.P: It is the abuse of our own, or vn∣iust pursuite of our Neighbours goods.

P.HI: How may a man be said to abuse his owne?

DIV3.P: By lauish spending, or couetous holding in.

P.HI: How by lauish spending?

DIV3.P:
When he layeth forth more in ap∣parell, diet, at play, and in building then his estate will beare: and, when he becomes surety, he cares not for whom, nor how farre. No, he that increaseth not nor bettereth his e∣state
by diligence in his calling, and prouidence in his spendings, .

P.HI: How by couetous holding in?

DIV3.P: When by a miserable mind, he robs. 4 8. & 6. 1, 2. & 2, 26. himselfe of the vse of that which hee hath in his owne kéeping, being thiefe to himselfe.

P.HI: So much for the abuse of our own goods: how doe we vniustly pursue anothers?

DIV3.P: Craftily, or without colour of Lawe.

P.HI: How craftily?

DIV3.P: By the deceit and wrongfull dea∣ling of a couzening tongue: as when wee buy or sell without conscience, not caring how cheap wee buy, how deare wee sell: and when wee bring into the Market, not , but a greedy minde to out bro∣ther.

P.HI: How without colour of Law?

DIV3.P:
When by a theeuish and strong hand wee take that which belongs not to vs; either openly as , or more closely as Pilferers: or in our hand that which is , whether found by , or lent to
or due to , as their hire.

P.HI: So much for that which is for∣bidden! what is commanded?

DIV3.P: To be with , and to rest in the that hath giuen vs; labouring by ∣gence in our lawfull callings, so to increase or maintaine it in Gods feare, that we may not be chargea∣ble, where we should be helpful and ease others: and, where wee haue done wrong to any, to put away theft by making restitution.

P.HI: So much for the preseruation of our neighbours goods: where are we charged with the care of his good name?

DIV3.P: In the next ninth Commande∣ment,Ninth Comman∣dement. which is: Thou shalt not beare false witnesse, &c.

P.HI: VVhat doe you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The occasion of the Commande∣ment, and matter thereof.

P.HI: VVhat was the occasion?

DIV3.P: Our and lying nature.Ps. 62 9. Esa. 57 4. Rom. 3. 4, 13.

P.HI: VVhat doe you obserue in the matter of the Commandement?

DIV3.P:
first, what is forbidden, and se∣condly,
what is commanded.

P.HI: VVhat is forbidden?

DIV3.P: Under the name of false witnes, which is an vncharitable report, true or false, wee are forbidden to wrong our neighbour, or our in good name.

P.HI: How many waies may such false witnesse be borne?

DIV3.P: Inwardly, and outwardly.

P.HI: How inwardly?

DIV3.P: When we suspect without cause, and condemne without hearing.

P.HI: How outwardly?

DIV3.P: Without speech, saying nothing: or, by speaking.

P.HI: How without speach?

DIV3.P: When we beare false witnesse inPs. 22. 7. Matt. 27. 39. lob. 16. 9. 1. King. 19. 21. Esa. 53. 3. Psa. 82. 4. Pr 4. 24. Deut. 33. 9. some mocking or disgracefull ges∣ture against our neighbour with the hand, head, tongue, or other mem∣ber; and refuse to the truth for him, being called thereunto.

P.HI: How by speaking?

DIV3.P: When wee giue forth, or receiue in some vncharitable report.

P.HI: VVhen beare we false witnesse in giuing forth a report?

DIV3.P:
First, when we speake truly, and
yet not eyther charitably, or with1. Sam. 22, 8, 9. &c. Ps. 52. 3, 4. 1. Sam. 23. 19. Dan. 6. 4, 5, 11, 12, Pro. 29. 11. Pro. 20. 19. 1. Cor. 13. 7. Ps. 31. 22. Ps. 12 2. 3. discretion of our neighbour: and, secondly, and chiefly, when we speak that which is false of him, or of our selues, and dissemble with our tongues.

P.HI: How many waies may we speake that which is false of our Neigh∣bour?

DIV3.P: In a lye, or vntruth.Col. 3. 9. Apo. 22. 15 Eph. 4. 25. . 5. 1.

P.HI: VVhat call you a lye?

DIV3.P: Whatsoeuer a man speaketh a∣gainst his mind, or knowledge. And1. Sam. 15. 20. Psal. 15. 3. Ps. 12. 2. lob. 6. 28. this, behind a mans backe is slander, and before his face, detraction by a lye.

P.HI: VVhat call you an vntruth?

DIV3.P: When a man rashly vttereth an vntrue speach thinking he speakethPro. 19. 20. true. And here we are forbidden to mooue false tales against our neighbour in presence, or behinde his backe.

P.HI: How many waies may we speak that which is false of our selues?

DIV3.P:
Either when we boast our seluesRom. 1. 30. Pr. 27. 2. 1. Sam 15 13. 1. Sam. 15. 21. 24. Gen. 3. 12. 13. 2. King. 5. 25. Ter. 2. 35 Col. 2. 18. vainely, or lessen our faults falsely, or excuse our selues by a lye: or when, by proud humility, we fall in
our speech that others may vs.

P.HI: So much for false witnesse in gi∣uing forth: what is it by receiuing in?

DIV3.P: It is such as concerneth our neigh∣bour, or our .

P.HI: VVhat say you of those who re∣ceiue a false report against their neighbour?

DIV3.P: That as they, who make it, haue the deuill in their tongue, so they, who greedily receiue it, haue him inPs. 15. 3. Pr. 17. 14. Act. 6. 13. & 7. 1. Pr. 14. 15. & 25. 23. their . And here wee are for∣bidden, as not to raise a false report with our tongues, so not to hold it vp (being raised by others) with an easie eare: that is, wee are for∣bidden both to tell false tales, and be∣leeue them.

P.HI: How may wee receiue a false re∣port concerning our selues?

DIV3.P: When wée suffer our selues to be attered in that which is false: or to be set downe vniustly by enuious tongues, thinking the worse of our selues for their detracting from vs.

P.HI: So much for the thing forbidden: what is commanded?

DIV3.P: To haue a charitable opinion of1. Cor. 4. 5. . 3. 17. Esa. 53. 9. Ps. 15. 2. Col. 4. 17. Leuit. 19. 17 3. loh. 12. 2. 2. Cor. 12. 11. 1. Cor. 15. 10. our neighbour, to speake the truth with a good affection, and to a end, abhorring to lye, as we would to be or be accounted the Deuils chil∣dren. Also, to speake louingly of others, and modestly of our selues.

P.HI: So much for the Commandements that concerne all acts and purpose of vnright cousnesse: where are we for∣bidden all motions thereunto?

DIV3.P: In the next last Commandement,Tenth Comman∣dement. which is: Thou shalt not couet thy neighbours house, &c.

P.HI: What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The occasion, and matter.

P.HI: VVhat was the occasion?

DIV3.P: The frailtie or ill disposition of our nature, declining from the rule of Charitie to our neighbour, and of Sobrietie to our selues.

P.HI: VVhat doe you obserue in the Commandement it selfe?

DIV3.P: The things forbidden & cōmanded.

P.HI: VVhat is forbidden?

DIV3.P:
The least and shortest thought orRom. 7. 7. Iam. 1. 14. . 4 14. desire of the heart against our neigh∣bour, tickling it to sinne, though we yeeld not to it. And, here all luss
are forbidden, contrary to charity on our neighbours behalfe, and tempe∣rance on our own.

P.HI: Of what sorts are these?

DIV3.P: They are either originall corrup∣tion, as it were the firebrand it selfe, or the effects, as it were sparks that flie from it. And, these are our fond wishings and wouldings, with other foolish thoughts of the mind, desires of the heart, and deepe of the head about matters, ten∣ding to the impeachment of our neighbours welfare, or of that vertue of contentednesse which wee should affect, and labour for in that estate and place, wherein God hath set vs.

P.HI: So much for that which is forbid∣den; what is commanded?

DIV3.P: Being contented with our portion,1. Tim. 6. 8. Psal. 16. 6. 1. Cor. 16. 14. 3. Iohn 2. Gal. 5. 16. 17. we must dispose of all our thoughts and wishings according to charity; wishing and delighting in our neigh∣bours welfare, as in our owne, and against all euill desires to the contrary, though of neuer so short continuance.

P.HI:
So much for the Commandements of duties to our neighbour in righ∣teoufnesse:
what say you of Sobriety commanded to our selues?

DIV3.P: This passeth through euery Com∣mandement of the second Table, cō∣manding Humility in the , meek∣nesse in the , cleanenesse in the se∣uenth, contentation in the eight, cha∣ritable truth in the ninth, and pure desires in the tenth Commandement.

P.HI: So much for the Law: what is due to those that breake it?

DIV3.P: Punishments, more or lesse in thisGal. 3. 10. Deut. 37. 26. life, and the wrath and curse of God to damnation, in the life to come: That is, paines temporal by ∣ments, and death, and paines eternalMat. 25. 41. of soule and body in hell.
That euerlasting fire, or treasuryMar. 9. 45. 46. of secret fire, prepared and kept in aLuk. 16. 26. place of the greatest distance from heauen, for the punishment of all vn∣godly sinners.

P.HI: Where is the place of hell?

DIV3.P:
God hath not reuealed. And, let vs, that haue the hope of ye Saints, rather endeauor neuer to feele it then to know it. When a house is on fire,
stand not to inquire how it came, but do our best to quench it.

P.HI: Wherein consist the torments of this place of hell?

DIV3.P: Generally, in these two punish∣ments, of losse and sense.

P.HI: What call you the punishment of losse?

DIV3.P: An euerlasting separation from God and Christ, which is a plagueLuk. 13. 28. 1. Sam. 4. 18, 21. 22. & 2 Sam. 14. 32. of plagues, and the very bottome of the of Gods wrath in full & per∣ torments of soule and body, after Christ shall say to the wicked on his left hand: Depart ye cursed into euer∣lasting fire prepared for the diuel and his Angels: Math. 25. 41.

P.HI: VVhy call you this separation from God, so great a plague and tor∣ment?

DIV3.P:
If the absence of the Sunne cause darknesse; what ioy must néedes be lacking, and sorrow abound where the Sun & God of saluation shall ne∣uer in the beautifull beames of his presence be séene any more? where shall be no more glimpses of fauour, but darke tempests and snares vpon all the nhabitants of that land of
? and where they so depart from God, , neuer to which made to say, that the tears of hell were not to of .

P.HI: Somuch for the punishment of losse: what is that of sense?

DIV3.P: That when euery member of the body, and of the soule shall beApoc. 9. 5. & 14, 10, 11. & 16. 8, 10. & 19. 20. tormented togither, not for some thousands of yeeres, and so an end; but for thousands vpon thousands,Mar. 9. 48. Math. 3. 12. Apoc. 10. 10 and thousands that no end. For, as the righteous say of Gods mercy, that his mercy endureth for euer: so, of his iustice the danmed may say,Psal. 136. 1, 2, 3, 4. &c. that his iustice endureth for euer.

P.HI: What is this called in Scripture?

DIV3.P: It hath many names giuen to it, toMarke 9. 44, 47 Mat. 22. 13 & 25. 30. shew how terrible it is; and therfore it is called hell fire: the wome thatApoc. 19. 20. & 20, 10, 14. neuer dyeth: vtter darknes: the bur∣ning lake, and second death.

P.HI: What do you gather of this?

DIV3.P:
If a man would not, to gaine the world, lye on a of wood for a very short time; how much and must the needes suffer, who shall bee tormented in a
lake of burning fire for euer? and, if a little disease in one part, so trouble vs vpon a soft bed; how shall the wic∣ked endure that worme of vnquiet conscience, that will, day and night (and not as a disease of some short time) gnaw vpon al parts of their , and powers of their tender mind; and, not vpon their pallats of ease, but beds of glowing fire?

P.HI: How doth the Scripture further, and for more terrour speake of this place, and the torments of hell?

DIV3.P: By calling it a place prepared forMath. 25. 41 the diuell and his angels.

P.HI: What gather you of this?

DIV3.P:
That as it would bee a grieuous thing to a man to liue a banished mans life in som dark prison, couer'd with deadly obscurity, but more grée∣uous to liue there among the most spitefull enemies of his father & fa∣thers house: so to be cast into a prison of eternal banishment from God, and pit of vtter darknesse, is a most woful thing; but it is much more wofull, not only to be so, but to be bound in chains of perpetuall fellowship with1. Pet. 5. 8. those, who (from the beginning haue
been enemies to man, and God, the father of mankind, I meane the Di∣uell, and all his vncleane angels.

P.HI: Shew this (yet) a little further.

DIV3.P: If Lots righteous soule was ver∣ed2. Pet. 2. 7. 8. so much, with the vncleane con∣uersation of the Sodomites, with whom he dwelt but for a time: how shall they be vered in soule and body, that are thrust into hel, that euer bur∣ning Sodom, where they must euer dwel with vncleane spirits & di∣uels; not to be broght out at last by the Angels, as Lot out of Sodō, but there to liue (world without end) forcing out desperate voices and cursings a∣gainst their former filthy liues, and present vncleane societie?

P.HI: Now where hel (thus described) is due to the breakers of the law, what do you gather?

DIV3.P: That, without repentance, all Ido∣laters,2. Cor. 6. 9. 10. Eph. 5. 5 Iam. 5. 12. Exo. 7. Num. 16. 33 Psal. 106. 17 1. Cor. 6. 9. 10. Apoc. 21. & 22. 15. customary and raging swea∣rers, rebels to gouernment, murthe∣rers by poison or with weapons, for∣nicators, thues, lyers, and of lyes must goe thither.

P.HI: And must Idolaters go to hol with∣out repentance, what (then) must Ido∣laters do to be saued?

DIV3.P: They must out of their Deut. 6. 2. (as an abommable thing) the ∣ty of , and serue the true God by his Word.

P.HI: What must customary and ra∣ging swearers do?

DIV3.P: They that take vp for a , the of the Holy One, that (if they be neuer so little in their ) they will prouoke him in his glory; and (if any thing go against hun) their tongues shall goe as against him, either in their games or more earnest , must (for hereafter) that great and fearefull name, the Lord their God.Deut. 28. 58.

P.HI: How, further, doe you perswade this dutie?

P.HI: What must lyars doe?

But they that vse the trade, shal not be in it. For, they are of

Therefore the distinction of lies into a malicious, officious, and merry lye, (as if any were lawfull) is not of Gods making. TheMat. 22. 20. 21. superscription is Caesars, and, it is not from heauen, but from Men.

P.HI: What do you conclude of al together?

Cor 1 30 23. 6. short of perfection: and, (doing the best we can) depend onely vpon God in Christ for perfect and meritorious o∣bedience, placed wholy out of our selues in him.

P.HI: To what end (then) serueth the Law?

DIV3.P:
To be the glasse wherein to view our estate in euery Commandement, that we may see how poore and vnable wee are to doe any thing worthy recom∣pence or pardon: and not to rest there,Mat. 3. 15. Ioh. 19. 30. Col. 2. 14. Rom. 8 33. 34. but to betake vs by Faith to him, who hath fulfilled all righteousnesse for vs, discharged with the pay of his Passion and obedience his Fathers debt-,
and brought vs our full acquittance in his death, and rising from death; that we might not dye but line.

P.HI: Then, it is necessarie that wee doe our best to keep the Law, though wee cannot be iustified by it?

For, when in the seuerall sums and parcels we shall find it impossible for vs to pay such a debt; it will make vs to fall into a right koning of our owne want and his worthinesse, that hath released vs from so great both debt and danger. DIV2.HEAD: The like short exposition of the Lords Prayer, in Questions and Answeres.

P.HI: WHat is Prayer?

DIV3.P: A religious calling vponPsalme 50. 15. remie 33. 3. the name of GOD by Pe∣tition, or with praise.

P.HI: What parts hath Prayer?

DIV3.P: Two, as Petition, and giuing of1. Tim. 2. 1. 1. Thes. 5. 17. 18 Thankes.

P.HI: What call you petition?

DIV3.P: A faithfull calling vpon the name ofPsa. 25. 1. & 4. 1 Pro. 30. 8. . 24 27. Ps. 25. 2. 3. Gen. 32. 11. God by request, or with suite, to pro∣cure some good, or to preuēt some euil.

P.HI: What do you gather of this?

DIV3.P: That God (only) is to be prayed vn∣to,Psa 65. 2. & 44, 20. 21, Ier. 31. 18. Rom. 10. 14. Iam. 5. 15. Mat. 7. 7. Iam. 1. 17. 43. 11. . . 4. and in faith: also, that with him are the , both of opening all good to vs, and of shutting all euill from vs.

P.HI: So much for petition: what call you giuing of thanks?

DIV3.P: A returne of all our receitsLuke. 10. 21. 1. . 29 , 11, 12, 13, &c. to God, with confession of his power in all, and praise for all.

P.HI: What difference doe you put be∣tweene prayer and praise?

DIV3.P: Prayer what we want, andLuke 17. 13. 15 16. . 66. 19. 20 praise confesseth what wee haue, and from whom.

P.HI: What doe you obserue here?

DIV3.P: When God openeth his treasurie,Psal. 66. 19, 20. wee must open our mouthes, that is, when he giueth his blessings, we must both acknowledge them, and be thank∣full for them; but so, as when he show∣reth blessings to vs, wee do not drop thanks to him, that is, praise him flew∣, when he giues to vs plenteously.

P.HI: What is true thankfulnesse?

DIV3.P: the saying, but the giuing ofMatt. 21. 30. Luke 18. 11. Gen. 27. 22. Psal. 50. 23. Psa 116. 12 Ps. 146. 2. . 29 14. Ps. 81. 1, 10, & 103, 1. hanks: and not thanks in word, but thankfulnesse in true obedience to the Word: and, not cold thanks, but ze∣lous from the heart, and faithfull with a single heart: and thanks in cheeull manner, and with continuance, not niggardly, and which hath soone done.

P.HI: Where haue we the best patterne of prayer and praise?

DIV3.P: In that absolute, most holy forme ofMat. 6. 9. 10, &c. Luk. 11. 2, 3, 4, &c. prayer, which we (commonly) call the Lords prayer.

P.HI: What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The preface, and prayer itselfe.

P.HI: What are the words of the preface!

DIV3.P: Our Father which art in Heauen: that is, thou that art ready to helpe vs, be∣ing the Father of Christ by Nature, and, in Christ, our by Grace; and art (not only ready) but able so to be, hauing thy dwelling in heauen, heare vs.

P.HI: What do these words teach?

DIV3.P: To come to God onely, and to comePs. 103. 13. Ec. 4. 17 . 3. 5. . 28. 17 Ec. 5. 1. . 23. 24. 1. . 8. 27 to him, as to a Father with boldnesse, and yet with reuerence; because hee is in heauen, and his the heauen.

P.HI: VVhat say you of the prayer it selfe?

DIV3.P: It is in the seuerall petitions, or confirmation of them.

P.HI: What say you of the petitions?

DIV3.P: They are such as belong to Gods glory, or our owne necessities.

P.HI: What are they that belong to Gods glorie?

DIV3.P: They are such as concerne the ad∣uancement of his glory, or the meanes.

P.HI: VVhat petition concerneth the ad∣uancement of his glorie?

DIV3.P: The first, which is: halowed be thyFirst Petition. name.

P.HI: VVhat doe you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The meaning, and thing taught.

P.HI: What is the meaning?

DIV3.P: That God in his person, titles, works, 28. 8. . 3. 14 Ps 68. 4. 6 Psal. 104. & 19, 14, & 138, 2, & 19, 7, 8, 9, 1. Cor. 11. 28, 29. Pr. 23, 1, 2, Col. 3 17 Psal. 96. 8. Mat. 5. 16. 1. Pet. 2. 9. Tit. 2. 10. Rom. 2. 24. word, Sacraments, holy ordinances, and whole religion may rightly be ho∣noured, and euer glorified. Also, that his name may be halowed in our good liues, and gedly talke, to the edifying of our neighbour in loue.

P.HI: What is the thing taught?

DIV3.P:
That they pray wickedly, who say, halowed be thy name, and, yet are or∣dinary prophaners of Gods name; that is, of his titles, Word, Sacra∣ments,
attributes of mercy and iudge∣ment,Exod. 20. 7. I. Lcuit. 24. 11. Iob. 21. 14. Psa. 50, 16, 17, . 2 13. Mat. 18. 20. Ezech. 8. 16. 1. Cor. 11. 22. 1. Sā. 8, 7. Luk. 10. 16. 1. Cor. 6, 15, 17, 18, Eze. 36, 20, 21, 22, Esay 52. 5. 6 Eze. 13. 19. Es. 28, 7, 8, 9, Hos. 4. 11. 18 Ps. 10. 5 Esay 57 1. Ps. . 6. & 149, 6, Esay 5. 12. Ela. 28. 14, 15, & 5, 19, 2. Pet. 3. 3, 4. Psa. 14. 6. & 145. 5, 6. & 78, 11, 42, & 28, 5, & 105, 5 6, works of Creation and proui∣dence, Sabboths, and other ordinan∣ces. Likewise who abuse his creatures to sinne, and neuer reuerence his pow∣er; as common swearers, common and intolerable despisers of GODS word, and ; all polluters of their owne bodies, with Adulterie, or Fornication, all filthy talkers and euill liuers, common drunkards, and other common and ordinary mockers, or not regarders of Gods strange and fearefull acts.

P.HI: So much for the Petition about the aduancement of Gods glory: what are they that concerne the meanes?

DIV3.P: The two next Petitions.

P.HI: VVhat is the first of them?
Thy kingdome come.
What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The meaning, and thing taught.

P.HI: What is the meaning?

DIV3.P:
That the kingdome of grace in thePs. . 2. 1 Cor 15. 25. Rom 14. 17. Ioh. 14, 16, 17, 26. Marc. 8. 14. Mat. 13. 19. Iob. 22. 22. Rō. 6. . Esa. 14. 4. 10. 2 Thes. 3. 2. Phil. 1. 23. Church, by the aduanced scepter of the meanes, inward, and outward, as the Spirit and Word preached, with all o∣ther holy meanes, may be set vp in ho∣nour: and that Christ would be pleased
to hasten his comming to iudgement,Apoc. 22. 20. 2. Tim. 4. 8. which is the kingdome of glory that we pray for here.

P.HI: What is the thing taught?

DIV3.P: That their prayers are sinnes whoPhil. 3. 18. . 44. 16 Act. 13. 45. Luk. 19. 14. 1. Sam. 2. 17. 2. Sam. 12. 14. Eze. 36 22. Ps. 51. 18. Psa. 122. 6, 7, 8, & 137, 6 7, & 83, 4, Psal. 20. . 2, 3, 4, . Tim. 2. 2. Psa. 2. 2. 3. 2. Sam. 20, 1, & 1. Sam. 10. 27. Am. 6. 3. are enemies to those means, not liuing in the spirit, and opposing to preachers: Also, who to pull downe Gods Church by their sinnes, neither wish∣ing the prosperity of it, nor welfare of the that are Fathers to t; and who put the day of the LORD farre from them, by their security in sin∣ning.

P.HI: So much for the first of those petiti∣ons which concerne the meanes of Gods glorie: what is the second?

DIV3.P: The second is in these wos: ThyThird Petition. will be done in earth, &c.

P.HI: What do you obserue therein?
What i the meaning?

DIV3.P: That the Will of GOD in his word may bee (not spoken of only or professed) but done; and done cheer∣fully, and willingly, with all faithful∣nesse, and constacie by vs men on earth, as it is by the Angels and Saints in Heaue

P.HI: What is the thing taught?

DIV3.P: That they pray in sinne and againstEsay 58. 3, 13 2. Tim. 2. 26. Esay 29. 13 Mal. . 8, 13. Heb. 11. 4. Luke 22. 3, 4. Agg. 1. 2 Nh. 3. 9. 20, 21. oh. 6. 66. themselues, who say to God, thy will be done, and do their owne or Satans will; or doe Gods will with no good will, nor readinesse, being (not cheare∣full doers of the lawe) but enemies to such, and so as Gods will is done in them, as in the diuels, not by them.

P.HI: So much for the Petitions that con∣cerne Gods glory: what say you of those that concerne our owne necessiries?

DIV3.P: They concern the things of this life, or of that to come.

P.HI: VVhat is that that concerneth the things of this li?

DIV3.P: The fourth next Petition, which is:4. Petition. Giue vs this day our, &c.

P.HI: What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The meaning and thing taught.

P.HI: What is the meaning?

DIV3.P:
That God would giue vnto vs (wal∣king in our callings) al things needfull for our present temporall life, whether for necessity or honest delights: and that he would remoue or put backe all things that may hurt or hinder it, as sicknesse, famine of bread, plague of pe∣stilence, warres and the like, with a
reseruation to his good pleasure in any, or in all.

P.HI: What is the thing taught?

DIV3.P: That they pray without faith and inNum. 11. 4. 6. Luke 12. 13 Math. 20. 11, 12. 20. Luke 12. 19. & 14. 18, 19 20. Dan 4. 26, 17 no good manner, who will be their own caruers in these things: or, who, ha∣uing the blessings of this life, hide their hearts in them, making them not glas∣ses, but veiles to God, that is meanes, by abuse, not to remember, but vtterly to neglect the giuer.

P.HI: So much for that petition, which concerneth the necessities of this life: what are they that concerne the necessi∣ties of the life to come?

DIV3.P: The two next Petitions.

P.HI: What is the first of them?
Forgiue vs our trespasses, seeing that5. Petition. euen we, &c.
What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The meaning and thing taught.

P.HI: What is the meaning?

DIV3.P:
That God will not lay our sinnes to our charge, and that in Christ he will forgiue them, and the punishment due vnto them: or, that he will iustifie vs, who are vnrighteous, in Christ the righteous; whereof we haue good te∣stimony within, when we can finde in
our selues a readinesse, freely and fullyApoc. 1. 5. Iob. 33. 24. Ph. 3. 9 Mat. 6. 14, 15 Luke 23. 34 Acts 7. 60 1. Cor 4. 13 2. . 6. 22, 23 to forgiue all those that haue offended vs.

P.HI: What is the thing taught?

DIV3.P: That they call for vengeance by all their prayers, that take vpon them (pa∣pstically) to satisfie for their , thatPsal. 130. 3. & 143. 2. Mat. 6. 15. . 2. 13 Mat. 18. 32, 33, 34, 35. Luke 6. 35. Mat. 5. 23, 24, 44. is, to make the amends for them here, or in Purgatorie: also, who come to pray without, or with a deceitfull for∣giuing of their brother.

P.HI: What is the second Petition con∣cerning the necessities of the life to come?

DIV3.P: The next Petition, which is: and6. Petition. leade vs not into temptation, &c.

P.HI: What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The meaning and thing taught.

P.HI: What is the meaning?

DIV3.P: That, in temptation, God would not giue vs ouer to conquered of sinne, or of Satan that tempteth to it: and that if he bring vs to the battell, he will conquer for vs, and (so) deliuer vs from euill, by loosing the power of sinne, and workes of the powers of darkenesse, that would binde vs to daation.

P.HI: What is the thing taught?

DIV3.P:
That they pray dangerously and sin∣fully,
who, praying against temptati∣ons,Ioh. 18. 25, 26, 27. Act. 19. 14, 16. 1. Ioh. 5. 8 Pl. 91. 11 Eph 4. 19. Gen. 34. 2. Ier. 5. 8 Gen. 6. 1. runne vpon the sharpe of them, ne∣uer caring by good meanes and proui∣dence to auoide those sinnes that they nde themselues most subiect vnto, by disposition of minde and corrupt na∣ture.

P.HI: So much for the prayer it selfe: what say you of the confirmation ther∣of?

DIV3.P: It is in the reason of the Petitions, or seale.

P.HI: What are the words of the reason?
What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The meaning and thing taught.

P.HI: What is the meaning?

DIV3.P: That our requests, hauing no other but God for their foundation or rocke, must needes stand sure in all stormes, seeing his Kingdome is strong, power infinite, and glory endlesse, who is to grant the same.

P.HI: What is the thing taught?

DIV3.P:
That they haue no assurance by theirLeuit. 10. 3 Rom. 1. 21 Luke 18. , 11, 12, 14. . 16. 29. Eph. 3. 20, 21. prayers, who, in them, ascribe not all to God, or, who take any little glory from him to themselues, or to their owne doings; crauing blessings front
him, and not giuing thanks vnto him.

P.HI: So much for the reason of the Peti∣tions, what say you of the seale?

DIV3.P: It is in the last word, Amen; or SoIohn 3. 33 it is.

P.HI: What do you obserue therein?

DIV3.P: The meaning and thing taught.

P.HI: What is the meaning?

DIV3.P: That wée pray with earnest∣nesse,Dan. 9. 19. Luk. 11. 8. 9. Psal. 84 11. Apo. 22. 20. 2. Cor. 1. 20. Marke 11. 24 1. Iohn 5. 14. and (confidently) with faith, be∣léeuing verily to receiue those things, which we haue according to Gods will in his word prayed for, and (so) put our seale vnto them in word of faith,

P.HI: VVhat is the thing taught?

DIV3.P: That they can haue no comfort in asking, who either pray not in faith and earnestly, or not for things (war∣rantably) to be prayed for.

DIV2.HEAD: An Examination before our com∣ming to the Lords Table.

P.HI: WHat doe you call the Sacra∣ment of the Lords Supper?

DIV3.P: Our growing vp withEph. 4. 15, 16 1. . 10. 16, Math. 26. 27. Christ by faith, resembled in visible signe, and effectuall seales of bread and wine.

P.HI: In comming to this Sacrament, what is to be considered by euery well prepa∣red Communicant?

DIV3.P: The doctrine thereof, and our ends of comming to it.

P.HI: What say you of the Doctrine?

DIV3.P: It is séens in the nature of the signs which are made Sacraments, or in their vses.

P.HI: VVhat say you of the nature of the signes?

DIV3.P: Their nature is to be seales of theMat. 26. 26, 28 body and bloud of Christ, that is, of the fruits of the same offred to vs by faith.

P.HI: Where haue you the seale of Christs body?

DIV3.P: In the bread.Matth. 26. 26

P.HI: Where, of his bloud?

DIV3.P: In the Wine.Matth. 26. 27

P.HI: So much for the nature of the signes: what say you of their vses?

DIV3.P: They be such as concerne the Brea Wine.

P.HI: What is that concerneth the bread?

DIV3.P: It is that which is seene in the brea∣king and giuing, or in the receiuing and eating of it.

P.HI: What doth the breaking of bread signifie?

DIV3.P: The wounding and breaking of the flesh of Christ for vs.

P.HI: What doth the giuing of it signifie?

DIV3.P: The giuing of Christ, the true bread,Iohn 6. 51 1. Cor. 11. 24 for our spirituall nourishment.

P.HI: What doth the receiuing of the bread signifie?

DIV3.P: The receiuing of Christ with theIohn 1. 12 Ephes. 3. 17. hand of faith in our hearts, as wee re∣ceiue the bread with our bodily hands.

P.HI: Who are reprooued here?

DIV3.P: The Papists, who say and beleeueBellarm. Tom. 2. . . gen. de sacr. Euch. lib. . cap. 18. &c. that the substance of the bread is tur∣ned into the naturall body of Christ, and that the people, carnally, receiue and eat their Maker.

P.HI: What say you against this grosse o∣pinion?

DIV3.P:
That a true naturall body, such as
Christs is, cannot be in two places atMath. 28. 6. & 26. 11. Heb. 10. 13 Acts 3. 21 1. Thes. 4. 16. one and the same time, to wit, in hea∣uen, and bodily in the Sacrament.

P.HI: So much for receiuing; what doth the eating of the bread signifie?

DIV3.P: That as bread doth nourish our tem∣porallohn 6. 54 and corporall life; so this is a Sacrament of our eternal nourishment in the life to come, and of our spirituall, in this life of grace which wee haue heere.

P.HI: So much for the vses of the bread; what be they of the wine?

DIV3.P: They bee séene in the pouring out, and giuing, or in the receiuing & drink∣ing of it.

P.HI: VVhat doth the pouring out of the wine signifie?

DIV3.P: The pouring of the oud out of hisMat. 26. 28 1. Cor. 11. 25 holy body for our sinnes.

P.HI: VVhat doth the giuing of the wine signifie?

DIV3.P: Our full nourishment in Christ of∣fered,Iohn 6. 55 Psal. 104. 15 not in his bodie only, but in his sauing blood.

P.HI: VVhat doth this teach?

DIV3.P:
That the Papists did, and still doe,1. Cor. 11 25 with iniurious sacriledge, detract from. . 2. tert. con. gen. lib. 4. cap. 22. de . &c. our assurance and Gods goodnesse, one
great helpe of our faith, by taking from the common people the vse of the Cuppe.

P.HI: So much for giuing: what doth the receiuing of the Wine signifie?

DIV3.P: That possession is taken of whole1. Cor. 10. 16 Ioh. 6. 56. Christ, while, after the receiuing of the bread, we, by faith, open our hearts, as1. Cor. 10. 3. 4 vessels, to receiue the trickling drops of his bloud, that nothing be lost.

P.HI: VVhat doth the drinking of, the wine signifie?

DIV3.P: The applying of the comforts ofGalat. 6. 14 Phil. 3. 8, 9 Christs passion to our drooping soules, as wine reioiceth the heart of man.

P.HI: So much of the doctrine of the Sa∣crament: what say you of our ends of comming to it?

DIV3.P: They be before, or in our comming.

P.HI: What is that which is before our comming?

DIV3.P: Our end before our comming is, toActs 8. 36 Iohn, 7. 37, 38 satisfie the earnest destre that we haue, or should haue of receiuing the promi∣ses of God vnder seale.

P.HI: VVhat bee the endes in our com∣ming?

DIV3.P: Such as testifie gifts, or receits.

P.HI: What be our gifts?

DIV3.P: Such as we giue to Christ the , or to the Church his members.

P.HI: VVhat giue you to Christ the Head?

DIV3.P: A heart well examined concerning1. Cor. 11. 28 c 15 21 Mat. 8. 8 our estate before we come, and serious∣ly meditating on Gods goodnesse in Christ, and our owne great vnworthi∣nesse when we are come.

P.HI: VVat els?

DIV3.P: An mble oblation of our selues,Rom. 12. 1 soules and bodies to him, with thanks∣g at our departure.

P.HI: in standeth the hearts ex∣a?

DIV3.P: In the xamining of our knowledge, , loue, repentance, thankfulnesse, and works of our particular callings.

P.HI: VVhat call you the examination of your knowledge?

DIV3.P: Whether I haue a competent mea∣sure1. Cor. 11. 29 thereof to discern the Lords body, & truly to put difference betwéene the signes, and things signified.

P.HI: VVhat of your faith?

DIV3.P: Whether I bee in the faith; belee∣uing2. Cor. 13 5 Math. 8. 13 hat te death of Christ, as it is a∣uail for all the , so it is (par∣ticularly auaileable for me.

P.HI: VVhat of your loue?

DIV3.P: Whether I bee in charity with allMat. 5. 44 Rom. 12. 18 men, euen with my very enemies, lo∣uing them vnto, and for their true wel∣fare; and not my friends only.

P.HI: VVhat of your repentance?

DIV3.P: Whether I acknowledge my sinnes with a sorrowfull and melting heart, and vnfainedly purpose to depart from all practice of them (heereafter) by a∣mendment of life.

P.HI: VVhat of your thankfulnesse?

DIV3.P: Whether I be ready to expresse it in my Christian conuersation, and new life for my redemption by Christ.

P.HI: VVhat of the workes of your parti∣cular calling?

DIV3.P: Whether with some greater mea∣sureLuke 3. 13, 14 . 4. 1, 2, 3 1. Cor. 7. 20 2. 10. of obedience, and better of better conscience, in all patience and good faithfulnesse, I walke, or do truly pur∣pose to walke therein, to mine owne great peace, and the benefit of those to whom God hath ioined me.

P.HI: So much for that which you giue to Christ the Head, what giue you to the Church his members?

DIV3.P: A fellow▪ stone in the spirituall buil∣ding;1. Cor. 10. 17 & 12. 13, 14 Eph. 2. 21, 22 . 4. 12, 16. that is, a member to help to make perfect the body of Christ.

P.HI: What doth this teach?

DIV3.P: That they that are negligent or pro∣phane commers to the Lords Table, do detract from the perion of Christs body, and seuer themselues from the society of his Church.

P.HI: So much for our giftes: what doe we receiue at the Lords Table?

DIV3.P: That, which we receiue there, con∣cerneth our selues alone, or our selues with others.

P.HI: What is that, that concerneth our selues alone?

DIV3.P: The strengthening of our faith and1. Cor. 11. 24. & 10. 16. 17. memory by the reuerent and right vse of that holy action.

P.HI: How is our faith strengthened, and olpen by it?

DIV3.P: ing that in the Sacrament,1. Cor. 11. 26 . 3. 1. & 1. Ioh. 1. 1. which but heare of in the Word, namely, the parcular offering and re∣ceiuing of Christ in his body and sa∣uing bloud, by all beleing Commu∣nicants.

P.HI: So much that which concerneth our selue alone: what is that that con∣cerneth our selues with others.

DIV3.P:
It concerneth our growing vp with
Christ, and our communion with our brethen.

P.HI: How do we receiue our growing vp Christ?

DIV3.P: We receiue it with Christ by spiri∣tual1. Cor. 10. 3, 4 eating and drinking, and by a more full partaking with him and his gra∣ces, through faith increased, and that vse his dinance blessed vnto vs.

P.HI: How do we receiue our communi∣on with our brethren?

DIV3.P: By our mutuall agrée∣ment,1. Cor. 10. 17 in as much as we eate (all) of one bread, and drinke (all) of one Cup.

P.HI: How else?

DIV3.P: By feeding all of the same foode1. Cor. 10. 4. & 12, 13. bodily and spiritually, and by drawing all life from the same fountaine; as the. 4. 15. life of grace which heere we receiue, and the lfe of glory, which, in heauen we shall be partakers of.

P.HI: So much for our examination be∣fore the Sacrament.

DIV2.HEAD: A short Direction for spending of time well.

P.HI: HOw doe you diuide the daies of mans life?

DIV3.P: Into the daies of labour, and daves of holinesse.

P.HI: VVhat say you of the daies of labor?

DIV3.P: These concerne the works of our cal∣ling, or workes of helpe vnto them.

P.HI: What be the works of our calling?

DIV3.P: The workes of that trade of life, in1. . . . 4. 1 which God hath placed vs.

P.HI: What must a man do in these?

DIV3.P: By offering them to God, he must walke in them neither slackly nor de∣ceitfully, but with Christian diligence and good conscience; following his owne businesse with quietnesse, and walking with God.

P.HI: Then, euery one must haue some spe∣ciall callg & trade of life to liue in?

DIV3.P:
, or hée is no sound mem∣ber of the Christian common wealth, a rotten member in the body of the
same, that deserueth a cutting off.

P.HI: So much for the workes of our cal∣lings: what say you of the workes of helpe vnto them?

DIV3.P: They concerne duties to be done be∣fore the worke, or that day after.

P.HI: What must we doe in the morning before our worke?

DIV3.P: Prayse God for his mercy the nightPsal. 59. 16. & 88. 13. past, and pray vnto him for his fur∣ther mercy and blessing the day pre∣sent.Gen. 24. 12.

P.HI: How shall we prayse God?

DIV3.P: By giuing him thanks, and by shew∣ing our thankfulnesse.

P.HI: How is our thankfulnesse shewed?

DIV3.P: Inwardly, or outwardly.

P.HI: How inwardly?

DIV3.P: By pleasing God in our vnderstan∣ding,Pro. 23. 26 Col. 1. 10. thoughts, desire, affections, and ill.

P.HI: How outwardly?

DIV3.P: By pleasing him in our words and deeds.

P.HI: How in our words?

DIV3.P: When they be gracious alway.

P.HI: VVhat things hurt this grace of speech?

DIV3.P:
Lying, swearing, brawling, lthie
speaking, foolish talking, thatEphes. 4. 25 Iam. 5. 12 . 4. . & . Col. 38 Pro. 26. 21 is not comely, and contention that cau∣seth stri.

P.HI: How in our deedes?

DIV3.P: These are in the duties of our gene∣rallRom. 12. 4 callings, as we are Christians: or our particular trades of life; wherein, some are Magistrates, some Masters and seruants, some Marchants, Arti∣ficers, Husbandmen, and the like.

P.HI: What are our duties as we be Chri∣stians?

DIV3.P: These concerne God or man.

P.HI: What are they that concerne God?

DIV3.P: They are in the foure Commaun∣dementsTit. 2. 12 of the first Table, called god∣linesse.

P.HI: What are they that concerne man?

DIV3.P: They concerne our selues, or ourTit. 2. 12 neighbour.

P.HI: What is that that concerneth our selues?

DIV3.P: Sobriety, which is inward; andRom. 12. 13. teacheth vs not to presume aboue that which is meete: and outward in our apparell, dyet, outward members and senses.

P.HI: What must our apparell be?

DIV3.P:
Such as becommeth those that pro∣fesse1. Tim. 2.
the feare of God.

P.HI: What call you sobriety in dyet?

DIV3.P: That grace of temperance that con∣siethLuke . 34 Rom. 13. 13 1. Thes. 5. 16. in the moderate vse of meates, drinkes, sleepe, and such outwarde things.

P.HI: What sobriety is that, which you call sobriety of sense, and the outward members?

DIV3.P: Sobriety of sense is a watchfulnes1. Tim. 4. 16. Ioh. 31. 1 1. Cor. 6. 15. in it; and sobriety of the members, a chastity in them.

P.HI: So much for the generall dety that concerneth our selues, called sobrietie: what is that that concerneth our neigh∣bour?

DIV3.P: It is contained in the sixe last Com∣mandements,Rom. 13, 7, 9 Mat. 19. 18, 19 Titus 2. 12. being Commandements of the second Table, called Righteous∣nesse.

P.HI: So much for our general duties, as we be Christians; what say you of our par∣ticular duties, or duties of trade of life?

DIV3.P: These reach vnto all callings in the Church and Common-wealth: but to our purpose, in a family, they con∣cerne the Husband or Wife, Parents or their Children, the Master and his Seruants.

P.HI: What is the Husbands dutie?

DIV3.P: To dwel with his wife, as a man of knowledge, by instructing her, and by1. Pot. 3. 7 Eph. 5. 28, 29 obseruing (for her better incourage∣ment) the good parts that are in her, and to loue her as his owne esh.

P.HI: What is the wiues dutie?

DIV3.P: To helpe her husband in the duties of the family: also, to feare, and to be subiect to him.

P.HI: What be the Parents duties?

DIV3.P: They concerne the father and nie∣ther iointly, or by themselues.

P.HI: What be their ioint duties to their children?

DIV3.P: In their tender yeeres they must in∣structPro. 22. 6 Ephes. 6. 4 Prou. 23. 13 Gen. 4. 2 1. Col. 7. . 37 2. Col. 12. 14 1 Col. 7. 39. them plainely, and season them with good things, young, giuing them due correction; and at more yeeres fit them for some honest calling; and when time serues, laying vp somthing for them, giue them in mariage onely in the Lord.

P.HI: So much for the Parents ioint du∣ties: what is the Fathers more speciall duty?

DIV3.P:
To prouide for his children; and spe∣cially1. Tim. 5. 8 to haue a speciall eye to the sons
of his house, as the Mother must to her daughters.

P.HI: What is the Mothers speciall duty?

DIV3.P: To nurse vp her children, if GodGen. 21. 7. 1. Tim. 5. 10. haue giuen her ability thereunto.

P.HI: What be the childrens duties?

DIV3.P: They be such as they owe to their Parents, or one to another.

P.HI: What duties doe they owe to their Parents?

DIV3.P: They owe them reuerence in theireuit. 19. 3. phes. 6 1. 1. Tim. 5 4 Gen. 47. 12. hearts, obedience in their deeds; and, when their parents shall be in yeeres & de, it is their dutie (if they haue wherewith) to nourish them.

P.HI: What duties do they owe one to a∣nother?

DIV3.P: To loue as brethren, & not to fall out.

P.HI: VVhat duties do Masters owe?

DIV3.P: They concerne Religion; and so they must help them to God by their in∣struction,Genes. 18. 19. Coloss. 4. 1. 1. Tim. 5. 8. Prou. 31. 15. & the care of their soules: or they respect their life here; and so pay∣ing them their wages iustly, they must make honest prouision for them.

P.HI: VVhat duties do seruants owe?

DIV3.P:
In singlenesse of heart, and all goodEphes. 6. 6. Tit. 2. 9, 14, 1. Pet. 2. 18. faithfulnes, they must do their masters worke, be true vnto him, and seeke to
please him, though he be froward.

P.HI: So much for our thankfulnes to God, expressed in our words and deeds, and for our duties the morning before our worke in prayer and praises: what du∣ties doe we owe that day after?

DIV3.P: They be duties, such as are betwéen or after our worke at night.

P.HI: VVhat must we do between our work?

DIV3.P: It concerneth our refreshings, or recreation.

P.HI: VVhat must we do at our refreshings?

DIV3.P: Pray before meat for Gods blessing, giue thanks, after, for Gods blessings,1. Tim. 4, 4, 5. Colos. 3. 17. Cor. . 31. Mat. 26. . 10. . 21. . 32. 6. vsing the same for strength or honest de∣light, and, no way for excesse, or drun∣kennesse.

P.HI: VVhat must we obserue in our recre∣ation?

DIV3.P: That our company be good, andphes. 5 7. 11. 4. 8 Thess. 5. 22. phesi. 5. 16. sports of good report, remembring that must be redeemed.

P.HI: When be our sports of good report?

DIV3.P: When they be lawfull for the na∣tureom. 14. 16. Co. 6. 12. , 3, 2 Thes. 5. 16, of them, and necessary for the vse, not hindring better duties.

P.HI: So much for the duties as are be∣tweene our worke: what must we doe after it?

DIV3.P: Examine our selues, as vpon an ac∣count, what we haue done the day past;Ieremie 8. 6. Psal. 4. 4. 8. and prepare our sleepe, that it may bee comfortable.

P.HI: How shall wee by such preparation make our sleepe comfortable?

DIV3.P: By committing our selues to God,1. Pet. 4 19. Ps. 4, 8, & 55, 16, 17, & 121, 4, 5, 7, 2. Thes. 3. 3. soules and bodies, praying him to in∣spire the soule with good thoughts, and to watch the body till the morning, that no hurtfull thing breake in vpon it.

P.HI: But some go to bed without praier?

DIV3.P: Such sleep in Satans lap, & haue him for their keeper: who (therefore) ma∣keth a thorow-fare in the thoughts of their heart, sowing the tares of many vnclean ccupiscenses & lusts therin,Mat. 13. 25. 26. which sown in the night, grow in ye day

P.HI: VVhat reason can you giue to proue the necessity of prayer, before wee goe to rest?

DIV3.P:
That night (for ought wee know) may be our long night, and that sleepe our last sleepe. Which if it be, (and the Lord hath seal'd no warrant to any that it shall not be) must needs bring small hope to our vnpraying soule, that it shal be glorified, and as little comfort to our body, (layd downe in so brutish forget∣fulnesse)
that it shall go to God at our next rising.

P.HI: VVhat do you conclude of this?

DIV3.P: That those Masters are cruel to their seruants, who suffer them to go to their beds, as wild beasts to their dens, with∣outPsalm. 19. 5. prayer, & do not better arme them a∣gainst the feare of the night.

P.HI: So much for the daies of labour: what say you of the daies of holinesse?

DIV3.P: On Gods Sabbaths, we must (first)Marke 1. 35. Exod. 20. 8. pray God to blesse the duties of them, and so keepe them holy.

P.HI: How must we keepe them holy?

DIV3.P: By doing as little worldly work assa. 58. 13. 48. . eut. 5. 12. may be, & by doing Gods work religi∣ously, and with all our might.

P.HI: In doing of Gods worke, what is to be considered?

DIV3.P: That we do the works that sanctiūe the Sabbath, and auoide the vnfruitfull works that defile it.

P.HI: VVhat works are required to the ifying of the Sabbath?

DIV3.P:
To preuent or defer, & by rising early 16. 23. Psa. . 1, 2, & 92, . 1. 5. . 1 Ephe. 6. 19. . 4, 17. . 84. , Acts 10 33 , 15, & 20. 7. & 16, 14 Deut. 11. 18. to dispatch all businesses that would prophane it; and, by praying God, to blesse his owne ordinances, to come with a spiritual & forward mind to pub∣like
prayer, preaching & Sacraments.

P.HI: VVhat other works are required?

DIV3.P: It is required further, before wee come to the assemblie, that wee pray, read, or heare some what read at home that may edifie; between the times ofLuke. 24. 14. Deut. 6. 7. publike exercise, that wee meditate on that which hath been deliuered; and af∣ter and between that we talke with o∣thers, and examine our selues about it.

P.HI: VVhat is (lastly) required?

DIV3.P: That we take a view of God in his works and word, pray, and reade, an sing Psalmes priuately; doe works of mercy; & consider Gods special works, of mercy, iustice, goodnesse and truth.

P.HI: So much for the works to be done: what are the vnfruitfull workes to be auoided?

DIV3.P: The spending of the day in sleepe, play, drinking, worldly talke or busi∣nesse, oolish communication, and things that separate from God by a carnall heart.
